title: Rankin webchat â your questions answered on Instagram, Madonna and big money | Art and design | The Guardian
summary: the good come out of nowhere .
i like that people think i look like james corden : he 's really funny and rather handsome .
there are never surprises when you 're photographing a celebrity .
stay tuned : we 're experiencing technical problems .
i was more scared of madonna than the queen .
if i was made prime minister , i would ban selfie sticks in museums .

documents.title: that 's all for today
text: thank you to rankin for coming to the guardian and thank you to everyone who asked questions .
ellyhoult asks : who would you have liked to have photographed ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 2:45pm i would love to have photographed muhammad ali , for obvious reasons .
happyjs asks : whatever happened to the diggers ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 2:44pm no idea .
i met one of them very briefly in scotland , i think they disbanded .
wordchazer asks : what do you think of today 's photo-sharing apps ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 2:44pm love/hate .
george wilson asks : i imagine you would n't have got where you are today without asking long shot questions ¦ can i assist you on a shoot in the near future ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 2:43pm email me .
info @ rankin.co.uk
thomasbetham asks : is a fixed focal length lens of 85mm always best for portraiture ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 2:43pm i have no idea - it 's always different .
i 'm the least interested in the technical aspects of photography out of all the photographers i know .
i love it when people say , `` your camera is so good '' - it 's not my camera .
it 's literally not !
cameras just capture light - the rest is about how you find that light , see that light , create that light .
nigel roberson asks : whose work inspires you ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 2:42pm i love lots and lots of different people 's work , but i always go back to four : bailey , newton , avedon and penn .
i think they just were more than photographers , and they were trying to capture what they saw in the world on film .
when i look at their photographs , i get a feeling .
how they framed it , what they did to get it , i do n't care about - it 's what they captured .
every time i look through their work i 'm green with envy .
they were my first loves .
i could name you photographers now that i love but they 're my peer group - it 's always a bit weird .
i love juergen teller , nick knight , david sims i really love photography .
that 's why i set up a magazine - we wanted to see people 's work in print .
we wanted to give people a platform .
i have n't lost any of that .
still now when i get a shoot in for hunger , i go wow !
that 's amazing !
i get a buzz out of it .
i 'm not just addicted to photography because of work - i 'm addicted to seeing it and consuming it .
that 's why i ca n't hate instagram , because it 's a great way of seeing work and being introduced to new work .
djramsay asks : do you ever use film or just digital ?
i was lucky to be photographed by you for your snog project .
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 2:40pm i use digital most of the time , but i love film .
i went through a period of thinking film was best i do n't care really .

the good thing about film is that if you were doing a project where you did n't want to share it with anybody everything in what you do in life can get boring , so changing it for a few days on a project is a good way of mixing it up .
my natural instinct is to please people and want people involved , so at the moment i encourage collaboration , and so i use digital .
but that does n't mean i do n't love film - i love everything about photography !
richard spence asks : which camera would you buy if you wanted to enter photojournalism with a paltry â£ 500 in your back pocket .
i know you prefer canon , but i would try any suggestion you have .
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 2:38pm i would buy a ricoh gr2 .
ilgatto asks : who are the underrated talents across various art forms that more people should know about ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 2:38pm there 's always underrated talents across any artform .
photography is a very strange creative process because i need so many people to create what i do every day .
i 'm the one who 's feted , and put on a pedestal - but with that comes the criticism and the crap .
make-up artists are called artists for a reason .
everyone i work with , i 'm privileged to get to work with some of the best people in the world , and they 're all underrated .
it 's becoming less like that though , because they 're now being recognised .
but at the same time , i could take on my own .
that 's why i think we get that extra validation .
ilgatto asks : what is your favourite comic book ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 2:36pm the beano .
or viz .

documents.title: the good come out of nowhere
text: felixdcat asks : 1 : which do you prefer black & white or colour ? 2 : when do you get your keepers : at the beginning of a shoot or at the end ?
or because you 're rankin , are they all keepers ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 2:36pm a really good question .
it 's always at the end or the beginning .
a lot of the time you 're struggling to get the at the end which is why it 's at the end .
they kind of come from nowhere , which is what 's exciting about it .
you might take 100 frames of someone , and generally it 's from 90-100 you get the keepers .
duncandunnit asks : did rankin come from a rather wealthy and privileged background ?
was his daddy and mommy wealthy ?
did he attend public school ?
from what i remember of my assistant days , rankin entered overnight and had very good agent , and the first time i met him , 26-odd years ago , he was well off .
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 2:35pm i did n't go to public school .
i 've never called my parents mummy and daddy .
they gave me money which helped me early in my career , but i worked my arse off - people will tell you i 'm one of the hardest working people in the industry .
sorry to burst your bubble .
i paid my dad back , with a lot of interest .
my dad was scottish , know what i mean ?
money was very serious in my house !

documents.title: i like that people think i look like james corden : he 's really funny and rather handsome
text: necesseter asks : how often do you get mistaken for james corden ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 2:34pm i do n't , because he 's a lot younger than me , but when i photographed him , we joked about how many people had said that we look like each other .
which i take as a compliment , because he 's really funny , and rather handsome .
exstalbans asks : if you ty earn â£ 100,000 for a photo shoot , do you think your privileged lifestyle compromises your work ?
do you think you are worth â£ 100,000 for a shoot ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 2:33pm i do n't get paid â£ 100,000 - that 's not to say i never have - but ty i get paid between nothing and what someone thinks i 'm worth .
i think it 's bizarre they pay me that much - how can anyone be worth that much ?
but ive worked for nothing , time and time again , and hopefully that balances itself out over time .
that 's not to say i 'm not successful - i am both commercially and financially - and i do n't take that for granted .
i love what i do and would do it for nothing .
did i mention i would do it for nothing ?
when you get paid that much money it 's incomprehensible .
if anyone says , i did 100 grand 's worth of work there , they 're mad .
but when you 're giving someone something that helps them make 20 million pounds , they 're going to think you 're worth that .
the balances hopefully level off .
i tend not to think about it .
if you start to think about it , you go a little crazy .
it would make me nervous .
you 're not being paid to be nervous - you 're paid to have an opinion .
and a lot of what that is is me being very honest with brands or whoever i 'm working for .
jamesehanson asks : what 's the best advice you were given when you were starting ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 2:32pm my mum telling me to choose a job i loved .
lisafryer asks : do you separate out what you already know about a person so you can capture them without preconceptions ?
or do you use gossip , reputation , etc to inform your approach ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 2:31pm that 's one of the best questions .
i 've not been asked it very often .
i really try to not ever believe anything i 've read or seen or heard when i go into a photoshoot .
you can be completely swayed by that stuff .

you can do your research , but you have to let it go , and base it on your empirical view of the person , because part of being a portrait photographer is being able to judge what 's going on in front of you , look in someone 's eyes and see if they 're telling you the truth .
that 's my job - trying to do that , and seeing their imperfections and insecurities and all the things that make them a multilayered human being , i 'm trying to capture an aspect or part of that .

i have to trust my instincts to do that , because if i trusted what people said , i would take shit what you see in planet selfie is the nice lighting that does n't let you see what the person is about .
you see a two dimensional recording of someone you want to see .
my job is to dig deeper , what are you insecurities , and make people feel comfortable to show the most honest side of themselves .
i 'm trying to find the honesty in the dishonesty of photography .
optimismisachoice asks : do you have personal projects ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 1:55pm literally hundreds - i have a file of ideas i want to do .
baldricksbrother asks : do you think you have created some of the most striking celebrity portraits ever ?
if so , which ones ?
was this your best shot or just a poor ripoff of the pink floyd wish you were here album artwork ?
was the image a dig at fashion , the shallowness and emptiness of the industry , or at some photographers , who take themselves far too seriously ?
what is your best shot now and why ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 1:54pm i do n't know if i even knew the pink floyd artwork when i took that although i 'm sure it was in my subconscious .
i always compare it to the buddhist monk who was set alight - what about that image ?
that was a documentary image , and mine was a critique of my industry .

it actually came from being at a party during a period where everyone was wearing nylon , and someone saying imagine if someone set fire to that person 's trousers , we would n't have a fashion industry .
the darkness in my personality led to that shoot .
i thought it was quite a funny comment .
yeah i have got a problem with people taking themselves too seriously .
but i 'm getting over it .
i do n't really have a best shot - i do n't love my shots that much !
wow , that shot 's brilliant !
i see holes , and i 'm very critical .
there 's a great saying , it might be bailey or newton - the next shot is your best shot .
the best photographers will think that .
we 're hunters , you 're trying to capture something - literally capturing it in a fraction of a second .
you 're chasing time , a moment , an interaction you 're always trying to catch something .
tomorrow is going to bring the best work you 've ever produced .
it makes you want to get better as a creative and as a human being .

documents.title: there are never surprises when you 're photographing a celebrity
text: streamliner56 asks : how much time do you have to meet someone for a portrait shoot , or is your preparation completed in isolation from the sitter ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 1:50pm most of the time , if you 're meeting someone famous , you do n't meet them beforehand .
i always quote david bailey - he said an hour minimum .
you want to get half an hour to get to know them , half an hour to shoot .
some people want to spend days with people - i 'm happy with half a day .
i do n't sit them down and talk to them , it 's lovely but unfortunately of how fame works , the pre-shoot thing just never happens .
it 's only on the day .
preparation for a shoot is done always with the knowledge of the publicist , so they know what they 're walking into - there 's never any surprises on a shoot .
which can be debilitating - i like to work in the moment , and that does n't necessarily go down well .
i 've learned to work with the culture of celebrity , and my approach even before digital was collaborative .
i felt like they were giving me their time and so i wanted it that way .
other people do n't approach it like that .

i always try to build up a relationship with everybody on the team so i never find working with publicists difficult , but the control that some famous people or their prs have on shoots , or even after shoots , can be frustrating .
for example , i was doing a book about portraits of people i 'd done over the years - i 'd photographed an actor in their early 20s and were 40 when they brought the book out .
i asked permission , and the publicist said : he does n't look like that any more .
it 's a retrospective !
and i got refused usage on the also some people that work around famous people have a lot of emails , so one-word answers are very common .
which can also feel a bit depressing .

generally i get on well with prs and see the need for them , because i 've watched other people try to get something out of someone , and not being respectful , not seeing the boundaries of professional to personal life .
that 's why i do n't have lots of famous friends - it 's about documenting what i see .
id3752362 asks : what advice would you give to my boyfriend , who is trying to start a career in photography ?
find a job and learn as you go or go try and go it alone ?
or neither of those things !

guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 1:44pm it 's hard for me to answer this , because i started on my own , i never assisted or tried to work for other people , but having seen a lot of my assistants go on to become very successful photographers , i would recommend assisting .
that goes back to the business question earlier on - it 's not just an artform , you have to earn a living , and being an assistant is also about learning the business side .
they see what it takes to put a shoot together .
i did n't assist - well , for two weeks , once .
i was quite headstrong when i started and there was a recession .
the idea of working for someone else did n't really appeal to me .
i was just hungry , and really wanted to succeed very quickly - but in doing so i grew up in public , very embarrassingly in some instances .
one of the things i took a long time to learn is that when you 're an assistant , you 're being paid for something , they 're paying for your opinion .
i thought i was a technician , and smudger as they used to call us .
but if you do n't give your opinion , you 're being dishonest to them .
be an assistant - choose someone you have affinity with .

barenakedsciolist asks : an itch i 've decided to scratch has turned into a rekindling of my passion for photography ¦ at one time , decades ago , i could produce a print from film using the old c41 process , some beers and a mate or two for company , but now i 'd be satisfied with just hanging a nice monochrome on the wall .
what would you suggest is the best route ?
process the black and white negatives in the sink and buy a negative scanner ?
or drop the canister at a processor ( if they are still around ) ?

guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 1:40pm i think if you 're getting back into photography because it was fun , then one of the fun bits is processing and seeing what you got on the neg , and then doing a contact sheet and a scan scanning is something worth knowing about , scanned images from a high street shop you 're never going to understand it .
try a bit of both and see what works best .
and we 're back ¦

documents.title: stay tuned : we 're experiencing technical problems
text: there is a hiccup in our commenting system and we will be back with you shortly .
id1681478 asks : how many unpaid interns is it possible to employ on â£ 100k per day contracts ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 1:38pm well , i have 60 fully paid staff members at my office .
we do pay interns , not a significant amount of money , but we do pay them .
i 've got another 100 at another office .
i do feel like i 'm doing my bit !
obviously things like this get said about you because people do n't like people doing well .
i take it on the chin .
all i know is i really tried hard throughout my career in supporting young creatives , and give people jobs .
percy17 asks : what is the future of photography ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 1:37pm it 's too big a question .
it 's exciting , people are taking more lots more rubbish but using photography as a language to talk to each other is so exciting .
i 'm very scared of seeing what it might be , and excited .
the language is really becoming part of the way we communicate with each other , on an hourly basis .
if you 're on instagram , you ca n't help but understand things it 's changing the way our minds work .
making us more sophisticated and more basic at the same time .

there are lots and lots of people in my business that use instagram as a resource for coming up with ideas , so what you 're getting is a regurgitation of ideas , which you could say is to do with the web but people are copying each other so much , so see really famous artists using other people 's work to influence their own work .
that 's a bad thing .
a good thing is how i can find out how my mate 's kid is doing at school , and i feel included in that shared experience .

and the way that mate of mine is taking the is evolving and he 's taking better so for young creative people who did n't have access to this in the past , suddenly they 've got this thing that 's very easy to use .
you 're going to have lots of really talented people coming out of it .
it 's in your hand , it 's very easily accessible , but at the same time it 's really easy to misuse .
but i 'm not an expert in this !
it 's just an opinion .
i do n't want to come across as a don of photography .
i 'd love , love , love to do a project on photography and social media , it 's untapped stuff we 're not talking about yet - no one is doing anything significant in terms of a broad look at it .
that 's accessible to millions of people .
obviously people are looking at it critically - i 'm talking about a big documentary on channel 4 or bbc about instagram , and how our language is becoming more sophisticated .
wankin asks : you said : at the end of the day , photography is 99 % business , connections and politics and 1 % creativity .
does that accurately reflect your career or do you regret having said it ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 1:31pm the question was specific to commercial photography .

at that time what i was saying was there was so much in it that was to do with not just business connections , also production , how you put a shoot together , make sure everyone turns up , all the technical stuff and production stuff takes up so much of it , and is so easy to fail at , that when it comes to the creativity it can feel small .
but that 1 % is more important than the 99 % .
i do n't think you should ever regret- you should own what you say .
saying something you regret can be a good thing , and admitting you 're wrong is really important as a creative person - morally , emotionally , all of the -llys , you 've got to cover them .
alexandra pearman asks : what drives your style of photography ?
and how to you keep it fresh and individual when there are so many photographers and forms of photography around ?

guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 1:29pm other people tell me i have a style , and i have to take that as a compliment , but i always think that very early on i made a decision not to have a specific style , because i did n't want to get bored , i wanted to jump around .
that 's how i keep things fresh - if i want to try something out , i try it out , i do n't have fear of failing though i have failed lots of times .

that 's just part of hte way i work - i do n't necessarily think things through before i do them , in the way artists or thinkers would , i use photography as my way of processing ideas in a more active way , and do it very publicly .
i 'm sure people get confused by me because of that .
i 've done a lot of projects where i do them i put them out and i realise they 're not very good .
but they 're strange , because those types of things loop back and inform you some other place .
i produce a lot of work , so a conceptual art photographer does a few pieces a year , i might do that in a week .
and i think photography is very visceral and should be about trying things out and experimenting and putting htem out to see how you feel about them .
it 's weird when you put something out and you see someone else see it - they do n't even need to say anything and you can see it 's a failure .
i 've got a very thick skin when it comes to criticism .
when someone says i think your photography is about this and that , i say been there , done that , i thought all that about a month ago !
my heart is on my sleeve , and so is my photography .
maybe not my brain
tinaeisen asks : our goals and ambitions make us get out of bed in the morning .
our belief that we can reach them drives us .
having met the people you have , shot the campaigns you have and earned the money you did , what excites you for the future ?
what are your dreams and ambitions at this point in your career ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 1:25pm it 's a tough one .
i think i 'm still learning about a lot of things , so i 'm at the point where i do n't have to work at all really , if i did n't want to .
i could retire tomorrow if i wanted to .

and it means that you start to take a little bit more seriously what projects you want to take on , so for the last year i 've been thinking about what i want to do next , but i 'm still going strong as a professional photographer .
to get into the zone i 'm in , i 'm one of a handful of people , so it 's a privlege and i do n't think of it as a privilege , i never take it for granted .
i 'm a freelancer , even though i employ nearly 200 people - i have to win the work , and i love that , i love the chase of getting the work .
that still excites me , but my personal work , my personal projects , i have so many of them in parallel .
i 've fulfilled all my dreams and ambitions - that i wanted to do 25 years ago .
now i'mn in that place where i do n't have anything i want to do , i 'm just enjoying being here and doing it .
but even the miniscule creative that some people think i am , i have ideas about other stuff , but they 're not fully formed yet .
i want to do a big , big project on something to do with people , but i 'm not quite sure what it is yet .
it 's very vague !
if i could photograph britain i love the diversity of it , and i 've been doing a lot of things i do n't know - maybe the thing in front of me is the thing i should focus on .
i 'm also keen to do a project on mental health , and the disenfranchised - the elderly , or people living in communities that do n't have a connection with those communities .
i 'm definitely putting my feelers out to people in mental health .
skeptical sam asks : what was the biggest challenge when you started your career ?
what 's your challenge these days while you 're a seasoned professional ?

guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 1:19pm there were so many challenges when i started that it 's hard to write them down in a sentence , but the thing that probably was the most difficult was that i knew nobody in anything .

my family were working class done good , and i came from the middle of nowhere with no contacts in the media , so when i decided to be a photographer my dad did n't speak to me for a year and a half .
he wanted me to be happy , but he did n't think i 'd be happy doing that .
they were equally supportive and scared i was making a mistake .

but because they 'd brought me up to make my own decisions , i 'd made that decision at the mercy of not having a great relationship with them for a bit - but if they had n't given me the guts to do it , i never would have done it !
it was weird .
it was tough .
i had to really go out and earn my keep in that year and a half - i had to work every single day , i had three jobs .
it was a really good learning curve , and i 'm glad my parents did that for me .
back then , to be a photographic student , it was very expensive - printing costs a lot of money , especially when you 're not very good .
the challenge these days for me is to keep fresh .
to keep doing new work that i think is of a high calibre .
because it 's very easy not to push yourself when you 're doing well , if you become well known for one thing it 's very easy to do that again and again .
so you just have to take on challenging work that scares you - which is why i do documentaries about documentary photography or hollywood photography , stuff i 'm not familiar with .
i 've just done one about people who are worried about having their photo taken , which is a challenge , but they 're such brilliant people .

documents.title: i was more scared of madonna than the queen
text: giannisdrakos asks : was madonna fun to work with ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 1:15pm yeah , she 's lots and lots of fun , and probably one of the most exciting people i 've got to photograph .
i was more scared of her than the queen .
she 's brilliant , and incredibly funny .
one of the best things she said to me was : `` i chose you because it looks like people are having fun in your that was my introduction - hello madonna !
i would work with her in a heartbeat .
robertnorbury asks : i think i have more freedom as a photographer than you have .
i use micro four-thirds cameras and reading lamps if i need extra light .
i do n't sell much , but i produce exactly what i want .
do you ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 1:14pm i do n't think any photographer has more freedom than me .
i have the ability to do any project ; i 've built up enough finance with my business .
i probably spend 40 % on projects that make money to spend 60 % of my time doing what i want .
but i 'm really glad you 're doing good - it 's great when people do what they want .
also as a footnote , my mum told me to choose a job that i loved , so i never go to work .
and i never go to work - i love my job , even when i get paid to do it .

documents.title: if i was made prime minister , i would ban selfie sticks in museums
text: kimmybrand : should selfie sticks be banned in museums ?

guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 1:12pm i hate selfies , myself , but i think that if people want to enjoy museums within a of themselves , then anything that makes people go to museums is a good thing .
though it can be annoying to other people so there should probably be a day a month where you 're allowed .
if i was made prime minister , which should never happen , that would be the first thing on my list .
i hate selfies because they 've become the homogenous visual representation of brand you .
and it 's the opposite of what really good photography should be , which is showing part of your personality .
they 're very dishonest .

i hate them because whenever i take a portrait now , people have this inner view of themselves , which i have to knock out the park - the first cricket ball that comes down my path is getting rid of the idea of the selfie .
when you take a it can be collaborative , or combative , a jostle - it 's not always bed of roses .
you have to break someone down and say : you do n't want to look like a selfie .
if i 've taken a selfie-style image of someone in my work , i 've failed , i 've created a piece of work that goes back into the homogenous system that i 'm trying to break down .
it 's the antithesis of what i 'm about .
they 're a pain in the ass , if i 'm honest .

the other thing is that there 's a belief that portraiture is dead , but what 's funny about that is that it 's more alive than ever - self-portraiture is very hard to disconnect from selfies , but any portrait photographer or painter is trying to get as far away from selfies as possible .
it 's almost easier now for me to take a good portrait .
msmariagoldstein asks : what was the most challenging aspect of photographing museums ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 1:07pm i have n't photographed any museums - i 've photographed the staff and patrons of those that were nominated .
my idea was instead of photographing famous artists , i wanted to photograph the people who come together to make a museum happen - i 'm a people person .
so there was a challenge , because it was what i do every day - but group shots are tougher , as everyone has an opinion , and people who work in museums have serious opinions !
but my job is to make people feel comfortable and get the best out of them .
highsmithp1 asks : can you speak about the set up of the fish love were people reluctant to have dead fish draped over their naked bodies ?

guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 1:05pm the fish love were unusual that they had to get very famous people to be photographed naked , and it was an awareness campaign about what we 're doing to the seas .

for me the idea of getting naked people and naked fish together was what interested me - i only do awareness campaigns if i think i can do something that may give people an insight into something they had n't had before .
i had no idea going in what we were doing to the sea , the ocean , worldwide , so it was surprising to me .
they said we 'll get celebrities photographed naked , and i thought it was a clever accessible way to get people talking about it .
in terms of photographing people nude , with fish , of course dead fish are really stinky , and they look beautiful but are n't that appealing .
and they 're dead , and it 's sad , especially these big tuna , these beautiful animals people found it strange .
but there 's no interesting stories a couple of people were reluctant to get naked .
i think it 's such an important issue , and it was a very good way of bringing attention to it .
and they went on to work with more great photographers , so i was really proud to be part of it .

documents.title: for fish love , getting naked people and naked fish together was what interested me
text: nigel roberson asks : for many , contemporary practice is in conceptual photography and the world of the everyday and the banal .
does this practice interest you ?
guardian contributor rankin1 21 june 2016 1:01pm all photography interests me .

i 'm a massive fan of photography - a superfan - and that 's why i do documentaries about photography , why i buy loads of books , have three of four magazines to publish other people 's work people forget i have really supported other people 's careers in getting started in photography .

however , saying that , some conceptual work does bore me a little bit - i have a theory which is that critics of photography think when you look away from the camera , rather than down the camera , it 's a more serious which i obviously do n't agree with .
but i love photography .

documents.title: rankin is with us live now
text: follow along here .
beaumont-thomas for the guardian

documents.title: post your questions for rankin
text: from a beatifically smiling queen elizabeth ii to an unreadable tony blair , with arnie , jacko and bowie along the way , scottish photographer rankin has created some of the most striking celebrity portraits ever .
he began dazed and confused magazine in 1991 with jefferson hack , and has also shot memorable adverts like dove 's real women ' campaign .

he can earn up to â£ 100,000 a day , but his most recent commission is more egalitarian : photographing the staff at museums shortlisted for the museum of the year award , and judging the public 's own images of the buildings .
he is joining us to answer your questions in a live webchat , from 1pm bst onwards on tuesday 21 june post them in the comments below , and he 'll answer as many as possible .

key_events.text:
2.41pm BST

The good pictures come out of nowhere

14:36
I like that people think I look like James Corden: he's really funny and rather handsome

14:26

1.19pm BST

I was more scared of Madonna than the Queen

1.16pm BST
13:16
If I was made prime minister, I would ban selfie sticks in museums

bulletin.text: The Dazed and Confused founder joined us to answer your questions and weighed in on everything from photographing Madonna to banning selfie sticks at museums. Catch up with his answers here.
